cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship's accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head:

LUXOR.
div.p: LUXOR HOTEL.–This old established hotel, accommodating 130 guests, is situated amid beautiful gardens with entrance on the river. Resident Doctor and Anglican Chaplain, Billiard Rooms, Bar, Electric Light, and all the conveniences of a first-class European Hotel. Tennis Court.
KARNAK HOTEL.–Under same management. Beautifully situated on river. Nice gardens. Guests taken on pension. Moderate terms. Excursions arranged to Thebes, Karnak, etc.

Sulphur Bath Establishment.- Sulphur water stronger than any in Europe. Eight European Masseurs and Masseuses. Every modern improvement.
Three-quarters of a Century's established Reputation

note.p: DJIBOUTI, December 11. Admiral Foelkersabm's squadron is prepar Ch ing to leave. It is supposed to be going to St Madagascar in order to await Admiral Rod Ma jestvensky's fleet. (Reuter.) Di
Port Said, Sunday. Several German colliers laden with coal for the Baltic Fleet are passing 26 through the Suez Canal bound to different ports in the East.
The British steamers Roddam and Yeddo, for reported to be carrying coal for the Russians, Th have been detained at Port Said and are dis- we charging their cargoes there.

Reuter's correspondent before Port Arthur describes the fighting preceding the capture of the 203-metre hill as being more intensely ferocious and bloody than anything previously th reported. Whole detachments were obliterated time after time. Every defence work was a block of bodies. Bayonets, clubbed rifles, and h grenades were constantly used. (Reuter.) C

The Pallada has sunk and is partly sub- merged. The Gilyak is fisting heavily and, D apparently, resting on the bottom. The Sevash topol has gone to the outer roadstead in order e to escape bombardment.
The Japanese cruiser Saiyen, whilst bom- barding Port Arthur on the 30th November, struck a Russian mine and sank. 38 men were t drowned. (Reuter.) E
TOKIO, December 10. C The Japanese cruiser Saiyen struck a mine A in front of Port Arthur and sank on the 30th November. Most of the crew were saved. (H.)
ST. PETERSBURG, December 10. Telegrams describing the battering of the Port Arthur fleet have been suppressed here. (Reuter.)
REICHSTAG-During the debate on the war budget, the Socialists opposed the increase of the army on the ground that Russia was crippled.

They renewed their charges against the Government of partiality towards Russia in the present war. Count von Bülow deprecated being guided by sentimental views in delicate questions of international policy. Such an influence caused people to take a wrong road in the South African war. He asserted Germany's complete neutrality, and ridiculed the suggestion that there was a secret treaty be tween Russia and Germany. The more the Press and the Socialists attacked Russia, the more he must exert himself to keep the relations with Russia peaceful and friendly. It is impossible to ignore the fact that there exist in Europe undercurrents leading towards war like complications, but Germany now-as in the past is the bulwark of peace, though solely because of her strength. (Reuter.)

Serious riots have taken place here to-day. A number of students of both sexes, who had gathered on the Newski Prospect, made a demonstration against the autocracy, and shouted for the war to cease. They were charged by the police and a struggle ensued. Many students were wounded and others (Reuter.)

ST. PETERSBURG, December 11. The students trade a manifestation on the Newski Prospect against the autocracy and the war. The police scattered them and arrest pd a large number. Fifty were wounded. (H.)
SHEPHEARD'S-We see that Mr. Scott-Leslie, the well-known entertainer's first humorous and s musical recital is announced for to-morrow night at Shepheard's.

NUNGOVICH HOTELS Co. - The Board of Directors of the Nungovich Hotels Company is now composed as follows: A. Rostovitz Bey, r-Chairman, Messrs. George Royle, Ernest to Stangen, Constantin, Meimarachi, Dr. Page d-May, and George Nungovich Bey, Managing -.) Director.
SUEZ CANAL-On the 7th and the 8th inst., rs 26 vessels passed through the canal. Of these,
16 were British, 1 French, 3 German, 2 Austrian, 3 Dutch, 1 Spanish. The receipts for the two days amounted to frs. 718,463.13. The total receipts from the 1st to 8th inst. is were frs. 2,508,157.42.

BRITISH CHAMBER OF COMMERCE.-We would call the attention of persons interested in Egyptian trade to the work of the British Chamber of Commerce of Egypt, whose office in Alexandria gives information as to stand- ings, trade, &c., to its members, and whose monthly publication reviews our commerce. The annual subscription is £1 and all British traders should become members. Our London office, 36, New Broad-street EC., acts as London agency to the Chamber.

We understand that Judge de Sausmarez, the Chief Judge of H.M.'s Supreme Consular Court, has been offered, and has accepted, the post of Chief Justice at Shanghai in succession to Sir H. S. Wilkinson. The salary attached to this post is £1,800, while that of the ur Supreme Consular Court Judgeship is £1,000.
Sir Ernest Cassel will return to Egypt at sly the end of January
Rev. and Mrs. F. B. M. Norman-Lee, C.I.F., and have arrived at the Grand Continental Hotel, .)Cairo, after a trip to Khartoum, and hope to return to Alexandria on Saturday next.

ub- The salary of Mr. Amic, of the Direct Taxes nd, Department of the Alexandria Municipality, as has been raised to L.E. 60 per month. At the der end of this month he will have the right to retire from the service of the Municipality.

The following passengers left for the Nile ere trip by the P. S. Nefertari on Friday:-Lady r.) Richards, Mr. Arthur Chamberlain, Miss Chamberlain, Miss C. Chamberlain, Miss K. Chamberlain, Rev. and Mrs. W. G. Wise, ine Mahmoud Pasha Sidky.
H.) It is stated that Judge Coghlan, of the Native Court of Appeal, will be transferred to the Mixed Courts in succession to Judge Law.

We regret to announce the death of Yous bashi Armstrong, of the Coast Guards Administration, which occured at the Deaconesses' Hospital, Alexandria, yesterday. The deceased returned from England from leave a few weeks back, and few days after his arrival here fell ill with scarlet fever. After an illness of some weeks' duration, pleurisy supervened. This CE." was followed by a very malignant form of small-pox, to which he succumbed. Yous bashi Armstrong had been in the Coast Guards Administration for about six years. His death will be deeply regretted by a large circle of war friends, as he was very popular.

We regret to announce the death, from the meningitis, of Mr. Archibald C. Rettie, assistant ain engineer at the Assouan Dam, which occurred ated at Assouan yesterday after only two days' icate illness. The deceased was a promising young aan man and his loss will be keenly felt and much road regretted.

The eleventh edition of Lord Milner's "Eng and in Egypt" has just appeared. The novel It is feature of this edition is Sir Eldon Gorst's exist sketch of the latest stage in Egyptian progress war which brings the history of England in Egypt as absolutely up to date, and is entitled "Egyp ough in 1904. The qualifications of Sir Eldon for ter.) such a task are exceptional, and this interest ing addition to this Baedeker to politica Egypt will be found in every respect worthy of the pen of the late Financial Adviser to the Khedive. The general merits of the work are too well known in this country to need any commendation from us, and the appendices of Sir Clinton Dawkins and Sir Eldon Gorst bring it as far as the present year. No inhabitant of Egypt who takes an intelligent interest in it o-day affairs, and has an acquaintance without had language, should neglect to procure this work deal which is published in a conveniently hand and form and at a moderate price.
England in Egypt. Eleventh Edition, Londer Edward Arnold, 41 & 48 Maddox Street, W uter.) Price 6.

The Winter Horticultural Show held at Ghe zireh on Saturday and Sunday was a thorough Ke ad success. Bright, if somewhat windy, weather prevailed, the exhibits reached a very high Iss standard, and Cairo society was there in large numbers. Among those present we noticed Mo H.H. Prince Hussein Pasha Kamel, the Earl and Countess of Cromer, Abani Pasha and Iss several of the Ministers, the Italian Minister and Marchesa Salvago-Raggi, M. Maximoff, M. Maskens, the Hon. F. H. Morgan and Sai Miss Morgan, M. Lecomte, Mr. P. Machell, Yacoub Pasha Artin, Mr. Courtenay Clifton and Mrs. Clifton, Dr. and Mrs. Keatinge, Mil- hem Bey Chakour and Miss Chakour, M. and Mme. George Nangovich Bey, Dr. Harold Im e, Nolan and Mrs. Nolan, Dr. and Mrs. Symmers, Dr. and Mrs. Elliot-Smith, Mr. Carton del ots Wiart, Dr. and Mrs. Mackenzie, Mr. A. J. Cotterill and Mrs. Cotterill, and many others. Iss The roses were a great feature of the show. For two years in succession there had been no exhibit of roses owing to the want of sufficient ld competitors, and the fine show of flowers, in many of them exquisitely beautiful in form ish and colour, was very gratifying after previous ice failures. The early vegetables also deserve Is d-special notice. Special encouragement had been se given to nurserymen to produce early vege e. tables for the market, and the results were shexceptionally good. The palms and decorative on plants in the central hall lent by Prince Hus as sein Pasha Kamel added greatly to the beauty of the exhibition, and we must not forget the I beautiful cut roses exhibited by the President of the K.A.S. but not competing.

ARMY OF OCCUPATION. INSPECTION BY DUKE OF CONNAUGT. and

pas The Duke of Connaught, as Inspector the Gekeral of Forces, is to make a tour of ag inspection in Egypt in Egypt in January. The du Dochess, who will spend Christmas with her an family at Bagshot Parkf will accompany her and husband.

Port Said, Sunday.-H.M.S. Espiegle, twin- screw sloop (Commander Lawrence de W. Satow) arrived at Port Said on Saturday morning, homeward bound from the China station. She will leave at daybreak to-morrow for Malta.
H.M.S. Fearless, 3rd class craiser (Com-to mander P. Vaughan Lewes, D.8.0.), also from China, arrived at Port Said this morning.

A Rugby football match between "Cairo" and ve "The Provinces" was played on Saturday last th at Ghezireh, and provided a great deal of athusement to onlookers, though we fancy that se the players found the ground unpleasantly hard. Cairo led at half-time by 2tries to 1, and A afterwards, aided by the fact that one of the W opposing half-backs, who had scored after a fine run, was "crooked," they won comfortably. an The Provinces were handicapped by the lu difficulty of raising a full team, some of their ot th best players being called away from Cairo on Saturday morning.
It is proposed to hold a Billiard Tournament at the Turf Club, Cairo, shortly.
i. A soccer match between the Port-Said team

and the Arab schools was played at Port-Said on Saturday afternoon, when an interesting game resulted in a win for the English team at, by 3 goals, which were scored by Messrs. Doyle Walls and R. Howe, to nil. It was noticed that the form of the Arab schools had much improved since last match, mainly due to continued practice.

RIVER TRANSPORT OF GOODS BETWEEN BLEYANDRIA & CAIRO

Having asked for an interview with the Khedive's brother, on hearing of his having is accomplished a long and interesting trip Sud h through several countries of the Continent during his recent visit to Europe, the Prince most kindly accorded me this honour and I called on his Highness a few days ago." The Prince, who speaks French and English fluently. st, was most gracious, and seated in the beauti ful garden of his palace, situated opposite the Savoy Hotel, I passed a very agreeable hour whilst his Highness gave me an account of h. his excursion.

"Accompanied by my private secretary and two European friends," began the Prince, "we, left Paris one lovely morning in July in a motor ear of the same type and make as that of the Empress Eugenie, on our way to Geneva, travelling at an easy pace and stopping at al, several places between the two cities. We stopped three days at Geneva, and the time was pleasantly spent in taking drives in, the beautiful neighbourhood of that delightful place, including an ascent of Mont Salèves, buried in eternal snows.

"From Geneva we proceeded to Chamounix T. and thence to Thonon, on Lake Leman, and passing Evicius-les-Bains, a favorite resort of or the Khedive, we went on to Bex. Here of again we made another three days stay and The during that time we drove to Viege (or Visp) her an old world village 2,160 feet above sea level her and picturesquely placed at the mouth of the Visp Valley. From Bex we retraced our steps to Aigle, another summer resort in the Ormont Valley, near the Rhane of lake of Geneva. At Aigle, I may say, commenced the win most beautiful part of the whole of our trip over the fine mountain road,and amidst magnificent day scenery we passed on to Château D'Oex,a quiet ina pastoral straggling village of between 2,000 TOW and 3,000 inhabitants. From this enchanting spot we proceeded over the Zwey Saanen pass to Interlaken, leaving the railway at Zwey- rom zimmen and passing several very pretty vil lages on our way to Lakes Thum and Brienz between which Interlaken lies. Our party made up its mind to stop here for 15 days,and spend the fortnight in making daily excursions over all the mountain districts in the vicinity. Of all the ascents we made during our, entire trip the most difficult was that to St. Beatenberg, the turnings being very sharp and the road and very narrow for so big a motor as ours was. last This small place, perched high up amongst of the mountains, nearly 4,000 feet above the hat sea, is a fairy like spot and favorite Alpine atly health resort on the north side of Lake Thum. and After visiting every part of the neighbourhood the we went to Lucerne, over the Brunnen Pass. P We rattled through Lucerne without stopping, and went on to a neighbouring village for luncheon and thence on to Brunnen, at the other end of the lake, by the lovely road or the Achsentrasse. Breaking our trip at Brun-le nen we made trips as far as Göschenen, on the T great St. Gothard Pass, and returning to o Brunnen we proceeded past Lake Schwytz to Zurich, putting up for five days at Dodler's d Hotel, on the hills near that town. From n ment Zurich we journeyed to Schaffhausen to see the illumination of the famous Falls of the Rhine w by Bengal lights. After two days spent here o we proceeded through Aaran to Basle and from the latter town across the frontier to Nancy f where we lunched. After resting we went on to o the Belgian frontier, where we arrived at 2.30 ting in the afternoon and had a most amusing con- tretemps, on account of the Custom House oyle being closed until 3 o'clock. We had to go back iced to Sedan to get gold money, notes being refused, in order to pay duty on the automobile, amounting to 2,300 francs. I should here add that I have not yet had this sum refunded and am writing to Mesers, Cook about it. A most amusing incident occurred between Nancy and wling the Belgian frontier. It was at night, and we were going at a very moderate pace, when suddenly two brilliant lights appeared in front of us and right in the middle of the road. We kets stopped at once, not knowing where the lights came from. Thieves there could not be surely so close to the two frontiers, but then where

1 did the lights come from 1 Slowly they approached and presently we heard a stern voice shout out Qui na la. We answered Amis, whereupon two gendarmes, armed to the teeth, galloped up and asked for our passports After carefully examining these and our motor car they allowed us to go on with a friendly "Bon soir Messieurs."

"From the frontier, we drove straight on to Brussels and after a two days' stay at the 0 Hotel Bellevue in that city, during which we paid a visit to Antwerp, we left Brussels for Paris, the whole trip occupying just one month ickets and a half. The weather, fortunately for us,

was very fine all the time. I drove the whole 6 six weeks myself. Before leaving I should like 1 you to say, for the benefit of others who may 0 wish to make the same delightful excursion, that in Switzerland the roads were mostly bad, the stones being simply placed on the ground for the wheeled traffic to do the rest of the ckets work, instead of the steam roller, In Belgium, again, the roads are also bad and the streets of most towns so badly paved that it is very disagreeable and almost impossible to drive at any speed. The best roads are undoubtedly those in Alsace and in France, but I should mer, add that, notwithstanding the execrable roads in some parts, we never had one breakdown, which proves the excellence of the French-build CAIRO Automobile."
And here the courteous Prince rose and, ying he had another visitor waiting to see LD. him, wished me good morning, as he heartily shook my hand,

The Governor-General and staff left Khars toum on November 7 to inspect the head quarters of the Bahr-el-Ghazal province, with the intermediate stations and the Upper Nile provinces. This is believed to be the first oc casion on which a Governor-General of the Sudan has penetrated into the heart of the Bahr el-Ghazal province. His Excellency spent two days at Wau, inspecting the station, troops, hospital, etc.

On November 18 he held a levée at which were present all the officers and officials the Roman Catholic missionary, and the prin- cipal sheikhs; among them Nasser Angil, of T'el Goma, and Moussa Ahmed Sultan, of Farog, and Sultan Chak Chak, an important Dinka chief from Dar Jandé. The Niam Nam Sultan Timbours, unfortunately, did not arrive in time for the reception. His Excellency made a speech explaining at length the aims and policy of the new Government. Slaverading and seizure of corps, etc., would never be allow ed, but peace and the prosperity of its subjects were the true aims and objects of the Sudan Government He warned all against the result of disloyalty and exhorted then to support the Government and labor for its and their own prosperity.
After the conelusion of this address, with which all present seemed much impressed, re- wards and presents were distributed to those who had assisted the Government.

His Excellency personally inspected the rubber plant, the development of which is now awaiting reports of experts. His Excelleney was particularly struck with the fine work and great difficulties overcome by the sudd-cutting parties on the Jur, and has ordered the explo ration of other important but sudd Blocked tributaries of the Bahr-el-Ghazal. The Jur river has been found navigable about 70 miles south of Wau for probably six months of the

Letters were dispatched to the Niam Niam Sultan Timbouro and N'Dorums regretting the Sirdar's inability to await their arrival, thanking them for the help they had given the Government, and expressing the hope that the Niam Niam nation would learn to respect and recognise Government authority, and obtain the ad- vantages of peace and settled rule."
Leaving Wau at 5 am. on the 19th Novem ber, the Sirdar proceeded to Meshra él-Rek and inspected Tewtikieh, Obok, Melút, Renk, Ka wa, and Duem, arriving at Khartoum 1 p.m. November 27.

The Ellerman S.S. Athenian arrived at Liver- pool on Saturday from Alexandria.
The S.S. Avoca, of the Westcott Line, left Malta yesterday and is due here on Wednes eday with general cargo from London.
